<tr>
<td style="padding-top:20px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good Saturday morning. </strong>It feels like summer here in New York City and we can't wait to sport some gnarly mask tan lines.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Before that, though, it's time for another edition of the New Normal, our weekly series exploring COVID-19's long-term impact on various sectors. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Today's topic of <strong style="color:#000"><em>higher education</em></strong> is dedicated to the Class of 2020. We can't imagine how weird things must be for you right now, but all we'll say is don't let a few months of quarantine overshadow all you've achieved in the last few years. Congrats!  </p>

</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Economic data: </strong></span><span>U.S. retail sales fell a record 16.4% in April as lockdown measures </span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/e95a6d2d0a721fcffb4efb9435b84f4f?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pummeled consumer spending</a></span><span>. Clothing store sales fell 79% from March and even grocery purchases dropped 13%. Online sales grew 21.6% year-over-year.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">More economic data: </strong></span><span>Industrial production </span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/2d7dd0b1ec74fcd9a06c489182e2ab50?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">declined 11.2%</a></span><span> in April. That drop is—wait for it—a record.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Stimulus: </strong></span><span>The Democratic-controlled House </span><span><a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/05/15/politics/house-vote-covid-aid-3-trillion-remote-voting/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">passed</a></span><span> a $3 trillion economic relief bill last night, but it's pretty much DOA in the Republican-controlled Senate. </span>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
HIGHER ED
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/15/colleges-universities-adjust-brutal-realities-coronavirus-pandemic?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
How to Throw a Disc on the Quad—Remotely
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="UVA" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC85NzUvdXZhLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em><a href="https://www.flickr.com/photos/gargola87/" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Mark Lagola</a> (original) and <a href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/User:Ben_Lunsford" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ben Lunsford</a> (this version), <a href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:University-of-Virginia-Rotunda.jpg" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">University-of-Virginia-Rotunda</a>, <a href="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0/legalcode" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">CC BY-SA 2.0</a></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The coronavirus pandemic has <a href="https://www.npr.org/2020/04/20/833254570/college-brace-for-financial-trouble-and-a-big-question-will-they-reopen-in-fall?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">put colleges and universities</a> in a financial predicament no string of all-nighters can solve. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>When governments rolled out lockdown orders across the globe, colleges had to scramble to get their enrolled students educated. And scrambling—shifting classes online, purchasing software, and teaching Professor Langdon how to use Zoom—costs money. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>But at the same time colleges were tacking on new expenses, many issued room and board and tuition refunds. And far less revenue is coming in for next school year. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The University of Michigan said it could lose up to $1 billion by the end of 2020, and many other higher ed institutions have frozen hiring, cut pay, and laid off staff. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">So how are they going to survive? </strong>Unclear...but some, like Southern New Hampshire University (SNHU), are making bold moves. Last month, the fightin' Penmen said they would revamp on-campus learning and <a href="https://www.unionleader.com/news/health/coronavirus/snhu-to-cut-tuition-from-31-000-to-10-000-revamp-on-campus-learning/article_03612259-97b8-5ff6-9e1c-134b8e8d375d.html?block_id=664693&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">cut tuition</a> from $31,000 to $10,000 beginning in the 2021–2022 academic year. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>SNHU said tuition-reduction plans were already in the works, but got fast-tracked when the pandemic and economic crisis showed up. </span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">So what will college actually...be like? </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Incoming freshmen at SNHU will live on campus and participate in clubs and activities, but all courses will be online (with in-person support from faculty).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">SNHU isn’t the only innovator.</strong> Arizona State University created a series of three “teaching and learning modalities” that provide students options <a href="https://freakonomics.com/podcast/covid-19-college/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">across the spectrum</a> of IRL/online learning, from a traditional on-campus experience to recorded video instruction they can watch on their own time.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>While some schools are devising creative workarounds, this is a seismic(ly bad) moment for higher education. George Mason economist Tyler Cowen <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2020-05-11/what-colleges-must-do-to-survive-the-coronavirus-crisis?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">writes</a> that the crisis threatens “the financial model that has sustained many schools and will force some to downsize, cut programs, or go out of business altogether.”</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">More than six in ten colleges plan to reopen with in-person classes this fall. You can keep tabs on all reopening announcements with <a href="https://www.chronicle.com/article/Here-s-a-List-of-Colleges-/248626?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">this tracker</a> from the Chronicle of Higher Education.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
INTERNATIONAL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/15/universities-face-large-losses-fewer-foreign-students?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Universities Risk Losing Their Profit Engines
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This fall, universities may lose their most reliable revenue stream outside of dining hall buffalo chicken wraps: international students paying full tuition.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The American Council on Education estimates international enrollment will drop 25% the next academic year as students face uncertainty over visa approvals and the status of fall classes. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Some universities are offering admission deferrals or waiving deposits and fees to incentivize students to commit. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>College deans are </span><span><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/what-college-look-like-fall-beyond-stephen-dubner/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">exploring</a></span><span> paths for international students to study online their first semester.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">They <em>really</em> need international students </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">State funding cuts have <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/13/amid-coronavirus-cutting-international-students-jeopardizes-colleges.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pushed colleges</a> to prioritize students who pay full tuition. And that was before a pandemic brought on stunning financial losses.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The number of international students was already going down. In the 2018–19 school year, U.S. colleges <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/education/study-finds-fewer-foreign-undergraduates-in-us-colleges--the-first-drop-in-13-years/2019/11/16/f20bdffe-07e4-11ea-818c-fcc65139e8c2_story.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reported</a> a slight decline in international undergrads, ending 12 years of growth.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>International students <a href="https://www.state.gov/international-education-week-kicks-off-with-open-doors-report/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">contributed</a> an estimated $45 billion to the U.S. economy in 2018, and studies show immigrants' presence in graduate programs <a href="https://www.cato.org/blog/dont-ban-h-1b-workers-they-are-worth-their-weight-patents?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">increases</a> patent output. Any significant drop-off in international enrollment this fall will have painful consequences. </p>

</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/15/covid19-refresh-college-applications?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Incoming High School Seniors Right Now
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="What do we do GIF" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=538 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/3og0ISDmwZW0z7W7HW/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="What do we do GIF" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/3og0ISDmwZW0z7W7HW/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">COVID-19 has toppled the pillars of college applications—entrance exams have been halted, grades made pass/fail, AP tests cut short, résumé-stuffing extracurriculars canceled. For the incoming class of high school seniors, it’s chaos. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Still...college admissions wasn't exactly operating like the ’96 Bulls pre-pandemic. Education experts hope the coronavirus will refresh an application process that, per NYU Prof. Scott Galloway, has <a href="https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/05/scott-galloway-future-of-college.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">turned into</a> “the most thorough and arduous job-interview process in modern history.”  </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Testing, testing</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">After canceling spring exams, the SAT and ACT will slowly resume later this year. But a record number of colleges have already <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/education/2020/05/11/high-school-junior-its-ridiculous-any-college-require-satact-score-admissions-during-covid-19-outbreak/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">scrapped</a> test requirements for the next cycle. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Good news for people who bubble in "C" and hope for the best: COVID-19 could accelerate the trend of making these exams optional.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The GRE, GMAT, and LSAT quickly </span><span><a href="https://statenews.com/article/2020/05/students-colleges-react-to-online-graduate-admissions-exams?ct=content_open&cv=cbox_featured&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">moved</a></span><span> online, but many graduate programs also </span><span><a href="https://www.ozy.com/the-new-and-the-next/grad-schools-waive-gre-gmat-coronavirus-pandemic/317727/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">relaxed</a></span><span> testing requirements.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>experts think the current application process fails to assess students on their ability to actually succeed. So what <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/opinion/2020/05/11/coronavirus-gives-colleges-chance-bring-sanity-admissions-column/3095627001/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">could change</a>? </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>More emphasis on high school grades/curriculum </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Fewer spots to list extracurriculars, since IRL is canceled </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Fewer essays, because everyone knows they don’t actually get read</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Students may also have to rely on <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/30/well/family/coronavirus-virtual-college-tours.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">virtual campus tours</a>. Silver lining: As universities invest in their digital presence, it’ll benefit students who haven't had the means to trek cross-country to look at 15 variations of the same leafy quad.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
COLLEGE TOWNS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/15/coronavirus-lockdowns-cripple-areas-surrounding-colleges-universities?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
College Towns Miss College Too
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Madison Wisconsin" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC85NzIvbWFkaXNvbl93aXNjb25zaW4uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When you’re in college, it’s easy to feel like you’re living in a beer bubble of paper-writing, pong-playing, and laundry mishaps. But you’re not. The areas that surround colleges and universities draw major economic benefits from them. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How? </strong>Universities fuel incomes through sporting events, professors who consult for local industry, research centers that attract high-skilled talent, and businesses on the receiving end of employee and student spending. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Higher ed institutions are all some towns have. In 2016, economist Lyman Stone <a href="https://medium.com/migration-issues/appalachia-is-dying-pikeville-is-not-fa583dac67de?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wrote</a> “it is not too much to say that the University of Pikeville is saving the city” of Pikeville, KY. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The point: no college is horrible for college towns</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">During the pandemic, revenue for municipal services like transportation have plunged and many local businesses may not survive. The director of the Edunomics Lab at Georgetown University <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/news/education/when-schools-close-students-leave-inside-america-s-empty-college-n1204356?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">explained to NBC</a> that municipal agencies can’t just flip a switch when population levels swing dramatically. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>“I’m not sure folks realize how much of an economic hit these small towns are going to take,” said MA state Rep. Mindy Domb.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ P.S.:</strong> Can you identify the college town in the image? Answer at the bottom of the newsletter. Hint: That big building is your clue...</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ADMISSIONS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/15/enthusiasm-gap-years-rise?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Maybe College Isn't the Best Idea Right Now
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Nothing elicits an “oh,” from parents quite like their children announcing they are thinking of taking a gap year.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But as the coronavirus cut short spring semesters and threw the upcoming fall semester into limbo, students and parents alike have been forced to consider <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/incoming-college-students-could-take-gap-year-over-covid-19-uncertainty-11588687598?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">hitting the pause button</a> before heading to college.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Google searches for “What is a gap year?” exploded by 180% in the last week of April.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Students must have liked what they found, because 35% of prospective college students are planning on </span><span><a href="https://www.axios.com/college-students-gap-year-coronavirus-pandemic-d3a2e2cf-a1f6-4b56-a395-4d936ca48c1c.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">actually taking a gap year</a></span><span>, according to one survey.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">There are two problems with 2020’s version of the gap year: 1) traveling is severely limited and 2) job opportunities are severely limited. Gap years themselves are <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-05-15/the-covid-19-college-gap-year-exposes-a-great-economic-divide?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">much less accessible</a> to lower-income students because...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Wealthier students can more easily go a year without school or work</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>They will still be able to afford college if/when they go back</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Some college administrators are urging students to <a href="https://www.freep.com/story/opinion/contributors/2020/05/12/coronavirus-college-gap-year-oakland-university-ora-hirsch-pescovitz/3109467001/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">skip the gap year</a>. According to Oakland University President Ora Hirsch Pescovitz, it’s “actually the perfect time to earn a degree.”  Worth noting—tuition and fees account for 30% of revenue for private colleges.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
WHAT ELSE IS BREWING
</h3>
</td>

</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/15/jc-penney-bankruptcy-filing.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">JCPenney</a></span><span> filed for bankruptcy.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><a href="https://www.axios.com/scoop-facebook-to-buy-giphy-for-400-million-4a75a359-833b-484d-b15b-87e94d3de017.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Facebook</a></span><span> is buying Giphy for around $400 million, per Axios, and plans to integrate it with Instagram.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><a href="https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/vice-media-laying-155-employees-1294736?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Vice Media</a></span><span> laid off 155 staff globally and its CEO said Big Tech companies posed a “great threat to journalism.”</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-huawei-tech-exclusive/u-s-moves-to-cut-huawei-off-from-global-chip-suppliers-as-china-eyes-retaliation-idUSKBN22R1KC?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The U.S.</a></span><span> further tightened restrictions on exports to Chinese telecom equipment manufacturer Huawei.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">

<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It's getting harder to squeeze all the amazing things our colleagues are doing into a single newsletter, but we're going to try. Here's the latest from across the Brew's growing universe...</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Go behind-the-scenes: </strong>Morning Brew’s lead engineer Tyler Denk <a href="https://medium.com/the-mission/the-tech-powering-the-morning-brew-machine-b7e8cd82121?source=friends_link&sk=210f631494c0a73f445742243c7b22cf&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">deconstructs the tech ecosystem</a> powering our content, sales, and web tools. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Write like the Brew: </strong>Check out writer Eliza Carter's <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/28/morning-brew-style-blog-2-let-sentences-breathe?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">latest blog post</a> on how to let your sentences breathe. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Unemployment info: </strong>Read writer Alex Hickey's guides on <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/07/jobs-reports-unemployment-gets-counted?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">who gets counted</a> in unemployment numbers and why states <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/14/state-unemployment-programs-unprepared-covid19?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">weren’t prepared</a> for the onslaught of jobless claims. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Social media goodness: </strong>One of our recent <a href="https://twitter.com/MorningBrew/status/1260706318551339016?s=20&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Twitter threads</a> should give you a good laugh.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Future of AI event: </strong>On Monday, Emerging Tech Brew writer Ryan Duffy will be interviewing two experts about COVID-19 and the future of artificial intelligence. <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2020/05/13/join-virtual-event-covid19-ai-adoption?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Sign up for the free event here</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000"><em>Shark Tank</em></strong><strong style="color:#000"> podcast competition: </strong>Have an idea for an episode of <em>Business Casual</em> you want to share with our team? <a href="https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/lDocpG?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Drop it in here</a> for the chance to pitch it live (<em>Shark Tank</em>-style) on Monday night at 6:30 pm ET. Winners get Morning Brew swag. </p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">With protective face masks taking center stage in the medical (and fashion) world, we picked out some of the craziest mask-themed headlines from the week's news. However, concealed behind one of these headlines is a story we made up. See if you can uncover it. </p>
<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>"Italian designer creates </span><span><a href="https://alt1037dfw.radio.com/blogs/camfield/designer-creates-the-trikini-a-bikini-with-matching-face?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">the 'trikini,'</a></span><span> a bikini set with matching face mask"</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>"These face masks come with a </span><span><a href="https://nypost.com/2020/05/12/these-face-masks-come-with-straw-hole-for-sipping-cocktails/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">straw hole</a></span><span> for sipping cocktails"</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>"Gucci halts production of its </span><span><a href="https://media.giphy.com/media/LpWmpM78HHoWOeQJIn/giphy.gif?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$6,000 masks</a></span><span> as customers complain about breathing through the leather"</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>"Men are less likely than women to </span><span><a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/men-less-likely-to-wear-masks-because-not-cool-study-2020-5?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wear face masks</a></span><span> because they see it as 'a sign of weakness,' a survey found"</span>
</li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"></p>

Clothing store sales fell 79% from March and even grocery purchases dropped 13%. Online sales grew 21.6% year-over-year.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eMore economic data: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIndustrial production \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/2d7dd0b1ec74fcd9a06c489182e2ab50?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edeclined 11.2%\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in April. That drop is—wait for it—a record.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eStimulus: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe Democratic-controlled House \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/05/15/politics/house-vote-covid-aid-3-trillion-remote-voting/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epassed\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e a $3 trillion economic relief bill last night, but it's pretty much width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC85NzUvdXZhLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/gargola87/\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eMark Lagola\u003c/a\u003e (original) and \u003ca href=\"https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/User:Ben_Lunsford\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eBen Lunsford\u003c/a\u003e (this style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eCC BY-SA 2.0\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe coronavirus pandemic has \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/2020/04/20/833254570/college-brace-for-financial-trouble-and-a-big-question-will-they-reopen-in-fall?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eput colleges and universities\u003c/a\u003e in a financial predicament no string of all-nighters can solve. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWhen governments rolled out lockdown orders across the globe, colleges had to scramble to get their enrolled students educated. And scrambling—shifting classes online, purchasing software, and teaching Professor Langdon how to use Zoom—costs money. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBut at the same time colleges were tacking on new expenses, many issued room and board and tuition refunds. And far less revenue is coming in for next school year. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe University of Michigan said it could lose up to $1 billion by the end of 2020, and many other higher ed institutions have frozen hiring, cut pay, and laid off staff. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSo how are they going to survive? \u003c/strong\u003eUnclear...but some, like Southern New Hampshire University (SNHU), are making bold moves. Last month, the fightin' Penmen said they would revamp on-campus learning and \u003ca href=\"https://www.unionleader.com/news/health/coronavirus/snhu-to-cut-tuition-from-31-000-to-10-000-revamp-on-campus-learning/article_03612259-97b8-5ff6-9e1c-134b8e8d375d.html?block_id=664693\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecut tuition\u003c/a\u003e from $31,000 to $10,000 beginning in the 2021–2022 academic year. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSNHU said tuition-reduction plans were already in the works, but got fast-tracked when the pandemic and economic crisis showed up. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eSo what will college actually...be like? \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIncoming freshmen at SNHU will live on campus and participate in clubs and activities, but all courses will be online (with in-person support from faculty).\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSNHU isn’t the only innovator.\u003c/strong\u003e Arizona State University created a series of three “teaching and learning modalities” that provide students options \u003ca href=\"https://freakonomics.com/podcast/covid-19-college/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eacross the spectrum\u003c/a\u003e of IRL/online learning, from a traditional on-campus experience to recorded video instruction they can watch on their own time.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eWhile some schools are devising creative workarounds, this is a seismic(ly bad) moment for higher education. George Mason economist Tyler Cowen \u003ca style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThis fall, universities may lose their most reliable revenue stream outside of dining hall buffalo chicken wraps: international students paying full tuition.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe American Council on Education estimates international enrollment will drop 25% the next academic year as students face uncertainty over visa approvals and the status of fall classes. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSome universities are offering admission deferrals or waiving deposits and fees to incentivize students to commit. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eCollege deans are \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/what-college-look-like-fall-beyond-stephen-dubner/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eexploring\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e paths for international students to study online their first semester.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThey \u003cem\u003ereally\u003c/em\u003e need international students \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eState funding cuts have \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/13/amid-coronavirus-cutting-international-students-jeopardizes-colleges.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epushed colleges\u003c/a\u003e to prioritize students who pay full tuition. And that was before a pandemic brought on stunning financial losses.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe number of international students was already going down. In the 2018–19 school year, U.S. colleges \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/education/study-finds-fewer-foreign-undergraduates-in-us-colleges--the-first-drop-in-13-years/2019/11/16/f20bdffe-07e4-11ea-818c-fcc65139e8c2_story.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereported\u003c/a\u003e a slight decline in international undergrads, ending 12 years of growth.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eInternational students \u003ca href=\"https://www.state.gov/international-education-week-kicks-off-with-open-doors-report/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003econtributed\u003c/a\u003e an estimated $45 billion to the U.S. economy in 2018, and studies show immigrants' presence in graduate programs \u003ca href=\"https://www.cato.org/blog/dont-ban-h-1b-workers-they-are-worth-their-weight-patents?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eincreases\u003c/a\u003e patent output. style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCOVID-19 has toppled the pillars of college applications—entrance exams have been halted, grades made pass/fail, AP tests cut short, résumé-stuffing extracurriculars canceled. For the incoming class of high school seniors, it’s chaos. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eStill...college admissions wasn't exactly operating like the ’96 Bulls pre-pandemic. Education experts hope the coronavirus will refresh an application process that, per NYU Prof. Scott Galloway, has \u003ca href=\"https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/05/scott-galloway-future-of-college.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eturned into\u003c/a\u003e “the most thorough and arduous job-interview process in modern history.”  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eTesting, testing\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAfter canceling spring exams, the SAT and ACT will slowly resume later this year. But a record number of colleges have already \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/education/2020/05/11/high-school-junior-its-ridiculous-any-college-require-satact-score-admissions-during-covid-19-outbreak/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003escrapped\u003c/a\u003e test requirements for the next cycle. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eGood news for people who bubble in \"C\" and hope for the best: COVID-19 could accelerate the trend of making these exams optional.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe GRE, GMAT, and LSAT quickly \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://statenews.com/article/2020/05/students-colleges-react-to-online-graduate-admissions-exams?ct=content_open\u0026cv=cbox_featured\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emoved\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e online, but many graduate programs also \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.ozy.com/the-new-and-the-next/grad-schools-waive-gre-gmat-coronavirus-pandemic/317727/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erelaxed\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e testing requirements.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003eexperts think the current application process fails to assess students on their ability to actually succeed. So what \u003ca href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/opinion/2020/05/11/coronavirus-gives-colleges-chance-bring-sanity-admissions-column/3095627001/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecould change\u003c/a\u003e? \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMore emphasis on high school grades/curriculum \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFewer spots to list extracurriculars, since IRL is canceled \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFewer essays, because everyone knows they don’t actually get read\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eStudents may also have to rely on \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/30/well/family/coronavirus-virtual-college-tours.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003evirtual campus tours\u003c/a\u003e. Silver lining: As universities invest in their digital presence, it’ll benefit students who haven't had the means to trek cross-country to look at 15 variations of the same leafy quad.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd Too\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Madison Wisconsin\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGetty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhen you’re in college, it’s easy to feel like you’re living in a beer bubble of paper-writing, pong-playing, and laundry mishaps. But you’re not. The areas that surround colleges and universities draw major economic benefits from them. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow? \u003c/strong\u003eUniversities fuel incomes through sporting events, professors who consult for local industry, research centers that attract high-skilled talent, and businesses on the receiving end of employee and student spending. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHigher ed institutions are all some towns have. In 2016, economist Lyman Stone \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/migration-issues/appalachia-is-dying-pikeville-is-not-fa583dac67de?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrote\u003c/a\u003e “it is not too much to say that the University of Pikeville is saving the city” of Pikeville, KY. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe point: no college is horrible for college towns\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eDuring the pandemic, revenue for municipal services like transportation have plunged and many local businesses may not survive. The director of the Edunomics Lab at Georgetown University \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/news/education/when-schools-close-students-leave-inside-america-s-empty-college-n1204356?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eexplained to NBC\u003c/a\u003e that municipal agencies can’t just flip a switch when population levels swing dramatically. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003e“I’m not sure folks realize how much of an economic hit these small towns are going to take,” said MA state Rep. Mindy Domb.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ P.S.:\u003c/strong\u003e Can you identify the college town in the image? Answer at the bottom of the newsletter. style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNothing elicits an “oh,” from parents quite like their children announcing they are thinking of taking a gap year.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut as the coronavirus cut short spring semesters and threw the upcoming fall semester into limbo, students and parents alike have been forced to consider \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/incoming-college-students-could-take-gap-year-over-covid-19-uncertainty-11588687598?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehitting the pause button\u003c/a\u003e before heading to college.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eGoogle searches for “What is a gap year?” exploded by 180% in the last week of April.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eStudents must have liked what they found, because 35% of prospective college students are planning on \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/college-students-gap-year-coronavirus-pandemic-d3a2e2cf-a1f6-4b56-a395-4d936ca48c1c.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eactually taking a gap year\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, according to one survey.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThere are two problems with 2020’s version of the gap year: 1) traveling is severely limited and 2) job opportunities are severely limited. Gap years themselves are \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-05-15/the-covid-19-college-gap-year-exposes-a-great-economic-divide?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emuch less accessible\u003c/a\u003e to lower-income students because...\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWealthier students can more easily go a year without school or work\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThey will still be able to afford college if/when they go back\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eSome college administrators are urging students to \u003ca href=\"https://www.freep.com/story/opinion/contributors/2020/05/12/coronavirus-college-gap-year-oakland-university-ora-hirsch-pescovitz/3109467001/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eskip the gap year\u003c/a\u003e.
